page.title: 15Farming: Wray: Animals, Land
page.content: At Higher Broadwood Farm, there were 110 sheep, 175 lambs, 40 cows, 18 bulls, a sheepdog and a Jack Russell terrier. The milk is bought by the Milk Marketing Board and collected by a milk tanker. Every year about ten old cows are replaced by ten new calves. Animals for slaughter are taken to Lancaster. In summer, the animals eat the grass in the fields but in winter they eat silo which is grass kept fresh by covering and making it airtight under a tarpaulin. It is cheaper and easier to make than hay, though hay is also made. The farm has 100 acres of land. The field names include: Top Meadow, Far Seeds, Holme, Meadow below t'road, Cow Pasture, Sandersons, Dodgsons.
